Lighting is subtle and romantic so thanks to tripadvisor reviewer who suggested bringing extra light if you like to read outside on the patio at night. We brought headlamp/ lighted ball cap and some votive candles. Enjoyed incence sticks that were replaced daily. The food at the restaurant was excellent; fresh ingredients, well prepared and interesting presentation. Bravo Chef Mariana! Prices are on par with fine dining in any good restuarant. Great staff. Guests were an even mix of 50-60ish folk and honeymoon couples the week we were there. No night life. We each had 2 treatments at the Spa and recommend the "Mayan Awakening" and Holistic Massage" treatments. Played golf twice at the Mayakoba course, which is great and about 10-15 minutes away; 5 when the road is improved. Insects were not a problem in our location, which was closer to the beach. Women should be aware that there are tiny midges that appear from the sand or ground at sunset in almost all seaside tropical locations that bite your ankles and lower legs. They can only jump an inch or so at a time and if they land on a sock or a man’s hairy leg, they don’t adhere to it. If you are eating on the beach at night, a pair of socks, although not elegant, will prevent you from having itchy ankle bites the next day. This information was given to me by a nature guide in Nevis. Dislikes: The road. Windows that don't open Likes: Everything else.

Reviews.Title: “Overpriced, nice in the $500-600 range...but not at $900”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Alway read Tripadvisor but never review. To return the favor, the Tides is my first. As a bonus, I included a small rant on mandatory service charges. In summary, we had a nice stay at the Tides and I wouldn’t discourage anyone from staying.. I simply think the rooms are average and price outside their range. But if there is a deal that puts the rooms in the $500-600/night range, then that’s different story. I know they have several promotions now that might make that possible. Here is how it stacks up in my view (with references towards it two peers --- Maroma & Esencia. Each which we have been to at least once) Staff Grade: A to A+ Reading some of the other recent comments, I suppose it is true that everyone has there own view of the world and two people have utterly different experiences at a same moment & place. I thought the staff was the redeeming quality of this hotel! They are personable, nice and did a great job. They always remember your name and seem genuine in their interest to make the stay pleasant. Things were slow at times (mostly around the dinner rush) but promptness was never an issue. Value for $ Grade: C My biggest issue is the price. Before I read JP3CHICAGO’s review, I had intended to say that if you stay in the Royal Villa (which we did), the extra $200/night it would be the biggest waste of money you will ever spend on vacation lodging. EVER! But maybe it isn’t that bad if the construction noise was as he indicated. I didn’t hear a thing except for mosquitoes (and they are pesky at the Tides due to the setting) and birds. To the point, I think, $900/night just doesn’t cut it. Strip-out the plunge pool (which is a novelty anyways) and the rooms are just average. For $575/night, Esencia’s garden rooms are far better. And you also get the “plunge pool” there. For $1,500, you can stay in the Cottage Rooms at Esencia with 2 stories, 2 bedrooms, a living room and your own theater/media room. PLUS you have a full size pool (the kind you can dive in) and the most beautiful terrace you’ll ever sit around. We stayed there last year and it was wonderful. Roomwise, amongst Tides, Maroma & Esencia (the three un-arguably best SMALL boutique hotels in Cancun)…Esencia wins hands down! Finally, on the rooms, I’m not a big fan of the DENSE Tides jungle setting around the room. The rooms are dark and mosquitoes problematic. But that’s my personal preference. Beach Grade: B The beach is much maligned. Yes there are rocks, but it adds character. The biggest negative is traffic…it is a very well traveled beach. So if you are looking for seclusion, you won’t find it here. Otherwise, it is very nice (the sand, palapas, service). Best beach amongst the three is probably Maroma, followed by Esencia. Food Grade: A to A++ The Chef is awesome and the food is great. Dining “anywhere, anytime” is a brilliant idea. The barbecue on the beach…tremendous. What the staff did from Valentines on the beach…awesome. Ambiance: B Adult only boutique hotels like this have boring clientle. I guess that includes me then! Finally, a rant service charges. How did we get to a point where a 15% gratuity is mandatory? It isn’t a convenience for me and frankly I’m tired of it. Let me decide! I really wish people would start pushing-back. I will pay 20% for good service at each and every place I stay…but if it is 15% mandatory, that’s all they’ll get. Maybe this policy of mine isn’t fair to the hard working staff…but that’s the way it goes. Though this is not endemic to the Tides, it did get my “goat” when I realized I was paying $200/night more for the service associated with the Royal Villa AND a 10% mandatory service charge on the full $900. Isn’t that what the $200 was for? Mandatory service charges need to stop. It has totally malformed (wanted to use another word but Tripadvior censor wouldn't let me) the whole concept of tipping and gratuities. So there you go.

Reviews.Title: “Recommend with reservations”
Reviews.Author: luxxtraveler
Reviews.Content: This was a beautiful resort, with a very attentive staff who had good intentions but didn't follow through consistently. The resort is all villas, some more private than others. We purchased the Royal villas, which are the same as the Luxury villas but slightly closer to the beach and inclusive of some additional amenities and service. I agree with other reviewers that under no circumstances are these extras worth the cost - book the Luxury villa instead. The villas are beautifully appointed, and the layout is lovely. Tthey are set in the jungle so the rooms are dark. The surrounding plant life is beautiful, but we missed the sun in our room. The lighting is dark in the room, but you can request brighter bulbs in the lights which you should do upon arriving. There are many places to relax and dine on the property, and they all have a beautiful view. From hanging beds with private curtains near the beach, to beach cabanas and poolside tables, everything was beautifully situated. The staff couldn't have been be more gracious and charming, but there was always a 30% chance that our requests would be forgotten. Normally this would be acceptable as a cultural difference, but at these prices, it cut into our enjoyment of our trip. The food was exquisite and wonderfully prepared. The chef is fantastic. We had a cooking lesson with her in the jungle and she was talented and charming. She was very accommodating to my vegetarian diet. The wine list is deep, and if you are a wine lover I would highly recommend exploring the Mexican wines as virtually none are available for export. They are of wonderful quality and their smoky-ness pairs well with the Mexican cuisine. The one culinary disappointment was the inclusive breakfast. A skant, hard, bad croissant with coffee, and sometimes tea. Given the quality of the resort, this felt off brand. Note that both the food and wine are extremely expensive, even by Manhattan standards. You can go into Playa del Carmen if you are feeling the pinch a bit, but the food won't be of the same quality. We found the city to be very Americanized, and not very authentic, so didn't spend much time there. We did scuba. We did a reef dive off of Playa del Carmen that was unremarkable, a cave dive in the Ceynotes that was quite unique and spectacular, and then a reef drift dive off of Cozumel (which required a pleasant ferry ride) that was also very stunning. We booked the first two dives through the Tides, but the divemaster there was a little flaky in communication style and pricing so we booked the last dive on our own. I would recommend researching dive sites before arriving so you know what you want so you can discussion options intelligently and can book the dives directly. If you want dive operator recommendations, please feel free to write me directly.

Reviews.Title: “Absolutely Perfecto!”
Reviews.Author: dlp49
Reviews.Content: As they say in Mexico, Perfecto! My wife and I returned yesterday from a truly remarkable 7 day stay at The Tides. The trip in from the highway along the back roads and through the other resort grounds at night during our arrival made us wonder if we had chosen wisely. However, from the moment we stepped onto these enchanted grounds we were treated like royalty. The level of service is beyond belief with waiters, butlers and management always discretely in the background waiting to assist you. The jungle like setting in which the 30 grass roofed villas each with their own plunge pools are located is idyllic. I even managed to create my own oil painting at one of the many quiet secluded areas on the premises. The beach is beautiful. The coral rocks are not a problem when wanting to swim since the hotel provides wading shoes and actually are very interesting if you look closely at all the sea life embedded in the coral. We cannot say enough about the food! We are heavy travelers and I have to say that the overall quality of the food is the best we have had at any resort. The varied cuisine and freshness of the ingredients is amazing. We have already committed to another trip next year.

Reviews.Title: “Shangri-La”
Reviews.Author: sylviaash32
Reviews.Content: The mile-long road going into The Tides from the main road consists of ruts, rocks, and potholes with junky stuff on either side. We weren't sure what we were getting into but once we were there, we gazed at a lovely Shangri-La with beautiful grounds, white sand beach with turquiose water, gorgeous swimming pool, and open-air dining facilities with view of the Caribbean. Each villa is nestled back in the jungle, each with it's own little pool-spa. Very private, very nice. The villa was great with a very comfortable bed and an excellent connection to the internet if you brought your laptop. Now for the drawbacks, most of which aren't terribly bad. The inside shower sprayed all over the place and was almost impossible to use but the outside shower was great. Only problem was, the outside shower wasn't lighted so couldn't be used at night. It's very hard for them to get the temperature right in the pool-spa...it's usually either too cool or too hot. There is no way for you, the guest, to regulate it yourself. The food in the restaurant is outrageously expensive even though it was quite good. The first night we spent over 2000 pesos on dinner. However that included two drinks and two glasses of wine. The next night we went to town ($15 dollar cab ride each way) and had a nice dinner and spent much less. The service is excellent and they try very hard to please you. All in all, it is a very nice place and we would go back. We are in our seventies and felt right at home even though practically everybody else was younger. That's always the way though!

Reviews.Title: “Once you get to The Tides, all is well.....very well indeed!”
Reviews.Author: mpwineca
Reviews.Content: My wife and I stayed at The Tides RIviera Maya for a week in early January. It exceeded our expectations in every possible way. The site is beautifully laid out. Our bungalow (No. 15) had every possible amenity including a lovely and private plunge pool. It was a short walk from the magnificent beach and even more magnificent restaurant on the property. We were extremely well tended to for our stay without every feeling smothered by the more than ample staff. They accommodated our every wish and could not have been more gracious. We took two cooking classes from the executive chef, Marianna Perez. She is an amazing artist with food and a very nice person as well. If you are looking for a unique and wonderful private beach vacation, this is for you. Cheap it is not. However, it is worth every penny. This is a place we will return to repeatedly for rest and relaxation. (The road to The Tides is another matter. Do not lose hope as you drive through HUGE potholes by some of the most rag tag looking places you have ever seen. They are apparently working on a new way to enter the property.)

Reviews.Title: “relax in the jungle”
Reviews.Author: sunlover033
Reviews.Content: Just back from 5 nights at the Tides. This resort prides itself on service . The staff was great , truely attentive and always right there for anything you might need. There are many paths connecting the villas and someone from the hotel is always right around the corner. They all know your name. The staff ratio is perfect to recieve all the service you want. It is easy to relax here since it is quite small and basically adults only, . Having a meal in privacy by the pool or on the beach add to the relaxtion and is hard to match anywhere else. There is plenty of seperation between lounges and chairs on the beach insuring as much privacy as you might want. Its a great place for a second honeymoon or place to reconnect. The villas, each w a with small private pool are tucked into the jungle.Each room/ villa is its own little oasis in the jungle The main pool next to the beach is wonderful. Due to the small size of the property no matter where you are you never feel crowded. The prices are a little high but it is easy to grab a bottle of wine in town for your room. Also defintely check out the town for some more excitement if you can pull yourself away from the peace and quiet of this wonderful place. After a few hours there we were totally relaxed . I would go back right now if I could snap my fingers and be there.

Reviews.Title: “Relaxation”
Reviews.Author: DallasTravelingmom
Reviews.Content: The Tides is hidden away where you wouldn't expect a wonderful resort. To get to it, you drive down a road in what seems like a horrible neighborhood. Keep going. You are in the right spot. The Tides is very small and personal. They call you by name. They remember what your preferences are. The food is delicious and Juan and Carlos are wonderful! The spa is relaxing and the treatments are good. I especially recommend the holistic massage. The prices are very high for food and drink. The negatives...you are in the jungle. There are lots of bugs. Bug spray did seem to help. There is construction surrounding you. The noise of the jackhammer in the first villa we stayed was extraordinarily loud. The resort did move us to a new villa for the rest of our stay. If the resort had been full the entire time, this would not have happened. Check on the status of construction before you book your room. Once the new resort next door and the one behind the resort (it may actually be one large resort and not two) are open, I am concerned that the beach will be flooded with people and the private atmosphere will disappear. We will have to wait and see. The beach is rocky as described. One bonus is that no one tried to sell me anything while I was on the beach. I have been to Mexico several times and you always know if you are sitting on the beach, you are going to be harassed by people selling their products. This didn't happen once. Lots of tourists walking the beach, but no one selling a thing! The staff is very nice and friendly. Very accommodating.

Reviews.Title: “such a bad time”
Reviews.Author: 897083-traveler
Reviews.Content: my vacation at the resort wasnt good like it was before, this was my second time at The tides, looking for the great time i hadbefore, but it was totally diferent. the service was fine, but not excellent i was expecting more because i was there a year ago but seems like people dont like guests there anymore(people who works there dont even say hello) the spa is not even the same, maybe they low their standarts because i didnt care paying a lot of money for a treatment because it worth it but this time was expensive and just bad service i got there looking for the great people who cares about theirs guests and it was sad to see people trying to sell something they just dont have anymore i was also looking for privacy and relaxing for and adult resort, and there was kids and even animals at the pool area

Reviews.Title: “Remarkable Place”
Reviews.Author: Gringo-in-Mexico
Reviews.Content: I agree with many of the other posted reviews, the Tides is a remarkable place in a nearly perfect tropical setting. However, the feeling that they are always trying to take every last peso never quite goes away. The individual palapa-style bungalows are absolutely incredible. Ours had a bamboo walkway through the jungle to our patio and plunge pool. The privacy offered is unlike anything I have ever experienced. We were initially concerned that the jungle would not provide complete shelter from the trails, but once we entered, we forgot all about anyone else. The rooms themselves are stunning and simply decorated. The high thatched roof provides most of the ambiance you could want. We took full advantage of the plunge pool and the outdoor rain shower and could not have been happier. The coffee and rolls that arrive each morning before you wake up and are placed on the outdoor table were a great touch. The common grounds are nearly immaculate and the service was excellent. As others have said, this stretch of beach is rocky, but you can walk 1/4 mile up the beach to a more gentle access. Or, you can case out the best route through the rocks and swim in front of the resort. However, the food and beverage prices are a little out of line. A beer from the minibar cost something like $8 USD and the restaurant and bars were way overpriced for what they serve. I don't mind paying resort prices, but there is a limit. Fortunately, the town of Playa del Carmen is a short taxi ride away (have them call a local taxi) and it is easy to get back to the resort (the driver may still know The Tides as "Ikal del Mar," its previous name). Playa has lots of great bars and restaurants and the whole town has a laid-back but very nice feel. We had the taxi stop at a shop and bought beer and liquor for the beach and the staff had no problem with it. They even brough us ice. Overall, an absolutely stunning resort with immaculate grounds, some of the best and most unique accomodations I have seen, and excellent service by really nice people. But, the incidentals are overpriced. A final note, with the 30% discounts that there are currently offering, the stay itself is a deal!

Reviews.Title: “the tides is tops”
Reviews.Author: tcs98
Reviews.Content: We stayed here for 5 nights and want you all to know that if you want fantasic service.a gorgeous beach.serenity and more romantic settings and wonderful meals than this is the place for you!trip advisor was a big help in making our choice for this resort,bye the way resort is not what it is .The tides is an intmate and special place for couples to unwind and re-connect.Not for people looking to party, head down the road for that.We will be returning! with only 30 bungalos the staff to guest ratio makes you feel like you are special!spa services are also excellent!

Reviews.Title: “money milking at Tides”
Reviews.Author: JonKIsrael
Reviews.Content: I'll start with the positives: The villas are very nice and designed in fine taste The beds are very comfortable The pool is attractive The spa is beautiful Most of the staff is personable The main problem: my wife and I constantly felt we're being swindled for more money. Examples: 1/We needed to finish our vacation a day early, because the economic collapse unfortuantely necessitated my return to work - undoubtedly an understandable situation considering the rare circumstances of the 2008 crash. They told us that despite hotel regulations, "things will be fine" with the last night charge. However, the manager that was supposed to authorize it wasn't to be found and did not come back to us for two days. Finally, we got hold of him when we were about to leave for the airport. He insisted we pay for the last night and only after some arguing was willing to cut 50% off the night's charge. 2/ We wanted to visit Maya ruins in the vicinity and were offered a day trip for close to $700(!). In the same breath, one of the staff offered for "one of his friends" to show us around for $350 - half the price, and was willing to settle for $250 - imagine what kind of kickback the hotel gets on those poor suckers who go for the full amount! We ended up hiring a taxi driver for a day for $150. That's right - one fifth of the original price. 3/ The hotel's shuttle to the airport costs twice as much as a taxi to the same destination. We therefore arranged for a taxi for our departing flight. However, when the driver arrived to pick us up, hotel staff told him he was mistaken, and that we were to leave the next day - this after twice verifying with us the day before whether we had airport arrangements! Shameful. BTW, the drive to Playa del Carmen using the hotel's driver also costs twice as much as taking a taxi into town. 4/ At the restaurant we were constantly pressured to order more drinks, as the waiters are partially compensated for alcohol sales. Twice we were surprised to find errors in our check related to drinks - charges for drinks that were offered to us on the house, and a charge for drinks we did not order. Other problems: 1/ The hotel beach is filled with rocks - it's dangerous going in and out of the water. Read: unrecommended. The staff openly admits "there's nothing to see" in the water. 2/ The hotel is quite un-ecological, what with towels and sheets replaced twice daily - with no option to forego the change (we simply put the "do not disturb" sign - a rope that "closes" access to the villa - to prevent the change). Bottom line: Tides Riviera has great potential, but we will not come back, and will not recommend it to our friends.

Reviews.Title: “Best Beach Vacation Ever”
Reviews.Author: heyul
Reviews.Content: We just got back from a 3 night stay and have nothing but wonderful things to say. The hotel grounds are amazing and well kept, the staff are courteous, kind and helpful, the villas were just amazing--sparkling clean, great linens, a portable ipod dock/speaker system... I was nervous about some of the former reviews that mentioned construction noise, as I tend to be the type of person that this would bother, but we heard nothing other than the waterfall outside our villa and birds chirping. (After walking the grounds, we realized that the vilas with the higher #'s, 30 and up, were the ones closest to the construction and probably have noise issues.)The food is good. Some things we had were excellent, some were so-so but all were carefully prepared and presented. Yep, it's expensive--especially drinks (Plan on lunch with a few drinks costing you $100) but we knew this would be the case. We actually grabbed a bottle of bourbon at the Duty Free while waiting for our luggage in Cancun--this turned out to be a great idea and saved us a few hundred on our bar tab... So I would definitely recommend this place for its beautiful setting, privacy and solitude---one walk down the beach to see the hordes of tourists at other hotel beaches will have you hightailing it back to the serenity of the Tides

Reviews.Title: “A magical place at the end of a dusty "road"”
Reviews.Author: jma5000
Reviews.Content: Keeping it simple, the Tides at Riviera Maya is a pretty great place. It was a tough decision deciding where to go in the Riviera Maya area, but we narrowed our destination down to Maroma, The Tides, and Esencia. We chose the Tides in part because of a 30% discount on the room rate and spa treatments and were glad we did. We stayed for 5 nights in a royal suite. Everything was pretty seamless, from the pickup at the airport to the activities we planned on the spot. We were picked up in a spacious SUV at the airport and taken 45 minutes or so to the Tides. The road leading up to the Tides is a bit odd... there are a few condo sites being built and there is basically no official road to get to the Tides, but don't despair, once you get there everything is great. Despite receiving notices of construction from the hotel, we heard nothing measurable from our villa, 22. The pluses: Great food (though a bit pricey, think New York City prices) but the quality was comparable to high-end New York City restaurants, so I'd say it is worth it... the chef, Cupertino, will customize your meals to your specifications, if desired. Ended up eating there every night. Staff is always available for any need... no searching for someone to help you. If you make a special request, they will honor it... for example, we requested extra water in the room and they remembered every day we were there. Rooms are cleaned twice daily and you never see them in your room....true housekeeping ninjas, similar to Aman Resorts style... Rooms are spacious and fairly luxurious, considering you are in the jungle. Large plunge pools are a great added touch... Beach is nice and uncrowded, no need to wake up early to secure cabanas... Pool is good-sized, given only 30 rooms at the resort Activities are easy to set up... recommend diving off Cozumel with Pepe, great experience. Also, snorkeling in the cenotes... Downsides (admittedly minor) The bill gets large quickly if you are taking advantage of the resort's offerings The beach is rocky at the shoreline, but clears up deeper in. However, water socks are provided free of charge, along with snorkeling equipment. Would be nice to have some rafts or other water "toys" plainly available, but to be honest I didn't ask specially for them. Water is nicely colored though. As you are in the jungle, you might be awoken by birds early in the AM, but this is to be expected and isn't entirely unpleasant. There are also some mosquitoes, but spray is provided everywhere on the resort. Overall, well worth it, especially if you can get a discount on the rack rates!

Reviews.Title: “I miss my hammock”
Reviews.Author: bostonkatie
Reviews.Content: I cannot say enough about this jungley beach paradise. We spent the second half of our honeymoon at The Tides (we left a highly-rated resort down the beach in Playacar early - too resort-ey and crowded, and the pool scene was trashy), and we promised ourselves every night we spent sipping Pacifico and Modelo Negro by the beach that we'd return for an anniversary or another special occasion. We had the time of our lives. At the main "lobby" (outdoor, under a palapa, with candles, and funky arm chairs, and tropical plants, and great magazines scattered about) we were greeted warmly - with icy cold coconuts with the tops chopped off, and a straw stuck inside - so we sipped coconut water while we were given the tour of the property and shown to our villa. Our villa was perfect. #38. The bed was like a cloud. Flower petals and turn down service every night. The bathroom and outdoor shower are unforgettable. Also the hand-made soaps with local ingredients and Molton Brown yummy smelling toiletries. Our villa was tucked away in the jungle, which, contrary to other reviews, we really liked because we had tons of privacy and nobody walking by our path at night. Hey, we had our own pool, and we were on our honeymoon. :) Something I really appreciated is that nothing was disposable. No paper napkins or plastic silverware. The soaps they gave us weren't harmful for the plants around the outdoor shower. They fill the grounds with native plants - they were planting more while we were there - rather than forcing crab grass, geraniums, etc., to grow. It's eco-friendly, but not crunchy. And the spa... ahh, the spa... get yourself at least the relaxation massage. Use those showers. Just incredible services, and a very unique experience. The food was delicious. Expensive, yes, but worth every penny. Especially after we tasted how the other half dines in the "nicest" resorts on the Riviera and the tourist traps in Playa del Carmen. No comparison to The Tides. We met the chef at the infamous beach barbeque on Friday night (just do it, you won't regret it), and he was warm, professional, and very interested in our feedback. I'm a vegetarian, and he had customized a four course meal especially for me - soooo good - and he was genuinely interested in my opinions on each course. I'll never forget that meal. The lunches and breakfasts were also fantastic (around $20 - $30 per person), and the service - everyone who works there - is impeccable. You feel like there are four staff members for every guest. They are attentive, but informal and not obtrusive at all. Manuel helped us on the beach, and he made our days lazy and fun and exactly what we dreamed of for our honeymoon. Victor was also funny and warm. Everyone remembered us by name. They wear ear pieces, too, and the lot of them talk back and forth all day... so they are free to roam the property but they can get you answers to your questions immediately. They also let each other know when a guests are en route to a particular space. We felt like they could read our minds all week. I have nothing bad to say. The windy, bumpy road keeps it exclusive and hidden. Even the construction noise (they are building a few more villas, and a condo property is being constructed right next door) was minimal. Some other guests we met mentioned that they were bothered by it one morning and mentioned it, and were accomodated well for having mentioned their complaint. The wine list is expensive, but we enjoyed several bottles of a delicious Mexican cabernet-malbec blend that was under $50 a bottle. We were delighted with it. All in all, this is a honeymoon/anniversary/couples paradise. It is another world. You just unplug and enjoy it. I read four books while I was there, and so did my husband, and we still talked ourselves out. There is nothing to do but enjoy the sun, the water, the space, and the person you came with. One note: this is NOT a family destination. Your kids won't have fun, and the other guests will likely be irritated. I love little guys, but not in a place like this. Or teenagers. You don't go to Rainforest Cafe or Planet Hollywood for a romantic dinner, and it's the same deal at this place. Kor Hotel Group is actually building a more family-friendly property in Playa del Carmen, and we were told it will be opening up sometime in 2009. Enjoy!

Reviews.Title: “The Tides this week”
Reviews.Author: melissamce
Reviews.Content: My husband and i just returned from a 5 day stay at the Tides. i would first like to comment o a few things that have not been on pervious reviews. I booked a royal suite, which basically means that you pay extra for treats to be brought to your room. This included, over the stay to be: 2 straw hats a silk scarf chocolates flowers in a vase fruit birthday cake/wonderful birthday night turndown candlelight/flower petals in room one night-you have to tell them that you want this and they are happy to do it Although i would not say that i had a private butler as advertised,but i was very well taken care of by all of the staff. I was unclear about the difference, and after witnessing it, i feel everyone was given the same attention service wise. It is over $100 more a day, so just know this if choose the royal suite. I viewed the presidential suite, and it was lovely. The other palapas are basically the same. Always ask for a room as close to the beach as possible. Not only are these away from the construction,they are less than a minute walk from the beautiful pool area. The hanging day beds on the beach front and in the garden(complete with waterfall)are reason enough to go to The Tides. This resort, in my opinion is NOT for any child. I saw some young teens there. Many of the guests are honeymooning and they make it clear how in love they are at any hour of the day.That is fine, but not if your kids are there. Service was excellent-such a friendly staff willing to do anything for you. They brought us a cooler after room service caught my husband trying to use a trash can. The air did go out one time, but it was fixed within 10 minutes of calling. Right now, there is some work being done on the property-maintenance has to be done! i am sure it will be cleared out soon. The construction work is ongoing, but it did not bother me one time. The sauna was not working while I was there. Very expensive, but overall a fabulous experience. It was really fun to meet the people i have heard so much about on trip advisor!

Reviews.Title: “Incredibly Romantic Escape”
Reviews.Author: BrynMawrBK
Reviews.Content: What a beautiful, romantic place! We spent the July 4th weekend here and really enjoyed most of our stay. However, I strongly disagree with the last reviewer who remarked that "the construction noise is not an issue". It was a major issue for us, as our villa was at the very back of the property and very close to the condominium construction site. We were awakened at 6:30 a.m. on Saturday by the loud construction noise, and had Julian, the manager, change our villa to a quieter one close to the spa. When you are booking, find out exactly how close your villa will be to the rear of the property, and try to get as far away as possible from it. With that said, the property is gorgeous and the villas are extremely private. It is certainly possible to swim in the ocean although there is a rocky ledge at the surf's edge -- the resort provides rubber "swim booties" with thick soles, allowing you to walk over the rocks without hurting your feet. Beyond the initial fifteen feet or so, the water is fine for swimming. On Friday night everyone dined on the beach in the moonlight with torches and sandpit fires burning, and the experience was unforgettable. The food is very good though not great, but we weren't there for the cuisine. This is a quiet couples hideaway kind of place, and it is perfect for that. There were numerous younger honeymoon couples as well as couples in their 40s and 50s who, like us, were having a kid-free getaway. Service was generally excellent and very friendly in a way that made us feel special, while still giving us our privacy. Drinks and meals are quite pricey, so be prepared. One final note: the power went out several times during one of the days of our stay, and the lack of air conditioning in the villa was brutal, even in the middle of the night. However, I don't know whether this is a common occurrence at The Tides.

Reviews.Title: “Our Honeymoon”
Reviews.Author: morgantc
Reviews.Content: Before moving here to Los Angeles, I lived in Hawaii on the island of Kauai and worked for many years in the tourism/service industry. One thing that was consistently stressed and instilled by my employers was, "the spirit of Aloha". This spirit was a vividly distinct hospitality and attention to detail that consisted of extending a genuinely warmhearted welcome into the family of local residents and extending yourself in ways that made the guest feel as though their time in Hawaii was spent with friends. My time in Hawaii and my pride in the level of guest service I provided has, however, left me forever critical and acutely aware of others in the same profession. I am delighted to say that that same spirit of Aloha is alive and well in Mexico. Jorge and his staffs' understanding of the service they provided and the manner in which they conducted themselves allowed me to positively and completely relax. I don't want to detract from what I was most impressed with in Jorge and his staff, but I would be remiss in not extending the same awe to Chef Cupertinos artistry. His talent is undeniable, and perhaps not as frequently appreciated. Some of the finest cuisine in all my travels. Lastly, the grounds keeping staff. They maintain just the right combination of indigenous flora and transplanted greenery in a way that I loved. Not too pruned, not too overgrown. You're left in touch with the jungle that transplants you to a time and place removed from the resort monstrosities mere footsteps in the sand away. A beautiful setting on a beautiful beach. The contruction noise is not an issue whatsoever. Period. Might i suggest, for honeymooners, the Mayan wedding ceremony. Made our stay truly moving and forever memorable.

Reviews.Title: “Eco-Chic Getaway at the Tides”
Reviews.Author: JLFLosAngeles
Reviews.Content: My boyfriend and I decided to stay at the Tides after researching hotels online because it looked like a beautiful and exclusive hotel where we wouldn't be among a lot of people and kids. We wanted privacy and romance and that is exactly what we got. The hotel has only 30 villas so we didn't see a lot of people around. We were alone in the pool quite a few times. The pool was spectacular with breathtaking views of the ocean! The service was outstanding. The workers knew our names and were very friendly and attentive. The food was amazing and also expensive. A romantic 5-course dinner on the beach or "BBQ" as they called it will cost about $300. A couple of drinks at the pool along with chips and gaucamole will cost around $60. The room was awesome with our own dipping pool and hammock in the front. We also had an encounter with a scorpion but we were surrounded by jungle so it makes sense. The room had a canopy bed and a large bathroom with a giant showerhead and my favorite Molten Brown bath products! The maids kept everything perfect and added sweet touches like flower petals on the bed and sculptures out of towels. The ride from Cancun airport was a little long though and when we started driving down the street to the hotel, I thought to myself this looks like a scene from the movie, "Proof of Life". Have your seat belt on because you will drive on the bumpiest dirt road ever surrounded on both sides by jungle and construction. I thought this cannot be right....but it was and once we arrived at the hotel I understood why the road was that way. It prevents a lot of people from going there which is a good thing. Overall, our vacation was awesome and I can't wait to return to Playa Del Carmen. I would definitely go back to the Tides!

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful, unique resort, but truth to some of the bad reviews.”
Reviews.Author: travelsnob77
Reviews.Content: The great thing about reviews on Trip Advisor is there is always some truth about the negatives. The same holds true for The Tides. If you are a frequenter of SLH hotels, Four's, Mandarin's etc. you expect 5 star service, food, accom. for 5 star prices. Its close, but isn't a Gold Lister yet. The positive's: Beautiful grounds. All that you read about it is true for the layout, and you do feel like you've found your own paradise within the jungle. Pool and beach area are clean, infinity pool and pool area sexy, well manicured, and peaceful. Its the Mexican Riviera, so the beach isn't The Nurse's beach in Kaui or Pink Sand beach in the Bahamas....its got some rocky patches, but its the way the beaches are on this stretch, not the hotels fault. Also saw a prior guest say jet skis are everywhere....yes true, but again, you're on a beach at a resort area....can't blame the hotel trying to make money renting jet skis. Rooms are spacious, clean, comfortable King bed, great bathroom- Molton Brown products (although is that really Molton Brown body lotion or just the bottle). Killer outdoor shower, the plunge pool is a great touch and the outdoor set up is spacious and comfortable. Also about as private as I've seen. We all know whats going on with outdoor showers and pluge pools and I've seen rooms with one on top of another with some screen seperating one pool from another. Not the case at the Tides....nice set up. Food is as advertised. Best I had in Playa...great chef. Food can be real iffy at most beach resorts I've been to, but not here. The Negs you've read in other reviews: First off I didn't book the luxury room w/a private butler. I would recommend doing this and paying the extra $ 150-200 a night if you want 5 star service. A number of times I had to call and ask 2-3x for water, to have my plunge pool temp turned up, on the jets to be turned on. Room Service took forever. You do hear the construction, it does start early, but its really not that bad. You do get a sewer smell...My bungalow was close to it, but again, its not that bad. You're in the jungle so there's bugs, duh! Had little lizards running all over the place and they make it in the room sometimes and had a flying beetle or cochroach fly into the mosquito net, but you have to expect that. I scuba dive and had a personal guide. I paid for it, but the extra $50-$100 I spent gave me a personal cenote dive and the aquatic guide is knowledgable. He will customize your activities. As with anything that is private or customized you have to pay and that should be no surprise to you. Meals are expensive, for Mexico way high, but the food is great, and for this type of resort, not uncommon. The one thing I would correct if I was management is trying to upsell guests on water, and tequila. You order 2 bottles of water and a shot of tequila they had you taste test and before you know it you just dropped $150. That's just crazy and a gouge job. I didn't appreciate that at all. They also all went to the United Airlines Premiere school of service. Yes, yes, yes, anything anytime...but ask for something a little out of the ordinary and its not today, or its not operating today...etc. They really do try and I'm just nitpicking for those of us who really appreciate the little touches and true 5-star service. If you're looking for a romantic getaway--relaxation, seclusion, with a lot of luxuries and a unique jungle type location, I recommend The Tides. If you're a penny pincher or thinking this is Mexico's version of The Ritz in Dubai, pass.

Reviews.Title: “Amazing Customer Service”
Reviews.Content: Tides is an A when it comes to customer service. We had a back room which was great for the price we paid. We arrived on Sat. night and then Sunday was great, but when we woke up on Mon. we heard the construction from the next door. We had the furthest room from the beach and the way the resort is set up there are only 3 or so rooms that can hear it. I called Mon. am and lightly compained about the noise on our vacation. They had the top of the hotel set us up with the Presidential suite and a comped dinner. The food is amazing and Cupertino can cook. This place rocks and was a great compliment to the Rosewood that we went to next. They were very nice and friendly to my wife and I. Regards, Brian

Reviews.Title: “Resort is 5 stars - the people make it 6”
Reviews.Author: kanNYC
Reviews.Content: We have recently returned from the Tides Riviera Maya. After we booked out trip we read the reviews regarding the construction and expressed our concerns to the management. Julian, the General Manager, assured us that everything would be alright and he would personally make sure that our stay would exceed our expectations. Needless to say, Julian's promise was fulfilled and The Tides gave us one of the most memorable vacations we have ever had. Their personal attention to each and every guest's needs are second to none. It all began with Luis our butler. Luis made sure that everything we needed from dinner reservations, to spa treatments, to adventures around Mexico, to special menu requests were taken care of for us and did so with a smile. Then there was Victor, our adopted butler. (Or as Luis would say - the PR department.) Victor was always on hand to ask how we were doing , remind us to put on lotion or simply to chat for a few minutes. Manuel at the Tequila bar knew our names by the first day and was quick with our favorite drink or a bottle of water all week long, before we could even ask him for it. One of the Nicest and most peaceful person we met was Vanessa the Spa Director. She personalized services to fit our needs and taught us Yoga every morning; allowing us to start the day with a clear mind, open heart and a smile. And, of course, there was Pepe and Santiago our personal tour guides. They showed us Tulum with colorful stories of people long gone and took us snorkeling in the cenotes. Not to spoil it but the trip with them is worth it just to get their special lunch. The Tides Riviera Maya is a Beautiful place not only for the location but more importantly for the people you meet. The hotel itself is second to none but the people that work there make it an experience of a lifetime. If you go please say hello to our new friends Julian, Luis, Victor, Pepe & Santiago, Vanessa and Miguel. They all made our stay amazing

Reviews.Title: “Serene Romantic Experience - Loved it!”
Reviews.Author: radanyc
Reviews.Content: I’ve never been to Mexico before and ended up doing a lot of research before our trip, relying mostly on tripadvisor. We wanted to have a romantic getaway and we were particularly looking for a small and very serene resort. After reading many excellent reviews about this hotel we booked a week-long trip. I was a bit nervous because this resort sounded too good to be true and I was very pleased to discover that it was all that and more! The Tides was perfect for what we were looking for – an adults-only romantic peaceful experience with excellent service and unbelievable food. We felt as though we were the only ones in the whole resort. Many things contributed to that feeling – the expansive grounds of the hotel, most of which is a jungle. The private villas were superb and we were able to be completely nude without anyone seeing us. The hotel staff was very friendly and helpful in every way. We felt like they were all at our service every minute of the day. So we really felt pampered. The private villas are beautiful – clean, nicely decorated, and incredibly romantic. I definitely wouldn’t suggest this place for anything other than romance. Every night we had a turn-down service. We’d come to our room from dinner and the canopy drapes were down, flower pedals everywhere, a page of love poem on the bed, and a very sensual music playing in the background. The beach was very comfortable and really beautiful. We didn’t go into the water because the beach is definitely rocky and the water was a bit rough most of the time. The pool is very nice though and even though I’m not a pool lover I enjoyed it very much. The food was amazing although very expensive – think $300 for dinner (including a bottle of wine). The dinner menu changed every day and so did the theme and the setting. One night we had an Argentinean BBQ with a bong fire, another a very romantic pool-side candle-lit dinner, another on the second floor of their open-air restaurant overlooking the pool and the beach. We went to Play del Carmen for a day once but didn’t really like it. I though it was kind of trashy and loud with tons of street vendors everywhere selling junk so we couldn’t wait to get back to our nice hotel! Now there was one big negative. I don’t know if we were unlucky (because no one else complained about that) but we had a few incidents with local jungle creatures. Seemed like all of them wanted to hang out in our room! There were multiple cockroaches and ants (both couldn’t get very far in due to the bug poison that the hotel sprays I guess, so they die as soon as they enter your room). One night we had a scorpion in our bathroom which we had to kill with a garbage can because the thing was huge. Another night we got a visit from an enormous caterpillar, also in our bathroom. So the hotel had to send a “team” almost every day to get rid of the “bodies”. I guess it’s smth to be expected when you’re living in the jungle but it was very unpleasant to see those creatures in our room.

Reviews.Title: “If you can afford it...nothing can be better”
Reviews.Author: lauraloo23
Reviews.Content: We stayed at Ikal Del Mar for our honeymoon...yes, it is very expensive. Yes, the drinks were very expensive. That aside, it was a dream. The location is beautiful. The rooms are luxurious, secluded, and very romantic. We spent our days relaxing on our patio or at the beach. We spent our nights drinking wine from thier wonderful wine list, and eating at the beautiful restaurant. The staff goes above and beyond. We do have one money saving tip though: We went into town and bought some beer and brought it back to our room. We kept them in the fridge, and we were able to drink pretty inexpensively during the day because of that. We will definitely be returning to Ikal Del Mar in the future.

Reviews.Title: “It is as good as the pictures!”
Reviews.Author: mthay
Reviews.Content: So, they have a killer website and I hoped that the property would be as beautiful as the featured pictures. It was. It also smelled lovely. The food is great. It is so peaceful and lovely there. The service is AMAZING! After we checked out, we drove to the airport., while waiting in line at the airport an hour away from the hotel, I saw that someone dressed in a uniform from Tides Rivera was waving at me. I went to talk to him, and apparently I had left my house keys in my room. He drove an HOUR to return them to me! Incredible service all around! The place is expensive, but I think well worth it. It's not a swimmer's beach, it's very rocky- but I think that there are beaches near. I am a real swimmer, and everything else was so great that I didn't mind that the beach wasn't a swimmer's paradise. I would go back again in a heartbeat!

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful and private luxury hotel”
Reviews.Author: muleqt99
Reviews.Content: We just returned from our honeymoon at the Tides and we could not have picked a better place- beautiful property, completely private, outstanding service, great food... you couldn't beat it! The villas were so beautiful and really very private. You have a private plunge pool and outdoor shower that are all blocked by the surrounding jungle. Fresh fruit and pastries are delivered every morning to your villa. We did get a few bug bites- but they do give you repellant and you are in the jungle! The most outstanding ascpect of the trip was the service. All of the wait staff, bar tenders, etc. all called us by name and new our tastes/preferences to a tee. The staff catered to your every need- bringing you a cold wash cloth on the beach, fresh towel when you get out of the pool, new bottle of water every few hours. One day we called for a ride to Tullum to see the ruins and the Tides arranged for a tour guide to give us a personal tour. It was amazing! Do not miss the Mayan BBQ on Friday nights! or the Tequila Tasting with Manuel! Two thumbs way up- already talking about when we can go back!

Reviews.Title: “A taste of heaven”
Reviews.Author: rsm10021
Reviews.Content: We have recently returned from our honeymoon where we spent the first 7 nights of it at The Tides and we are still talking about it !!! It's just like being in paradise at the resort. From the moment we arrived we felt like part of a family. The staff are the best I have ever known, so friendly and courteous and couldn't do enough for us especially Ligia, Victor, Roger, Manuel, Alberto and Lewis - they were fantastic. The spa was superb too and every treatment we had we were thrilled with and felt like we were floating on air. The Villa #22 was amazing - so romantic and special and we loved coming back to our villa each day to see what animal they had made out of towels on our bed. The outdoor shower was amazing and just being surrounded by nature and hearing the sounds of the gorgeous birds singing each morning was a truely amazing experience - we loved it. We were worried about the construction after reading other reviews on trip advisor but we didn't hear a thing and it didn't affect us in any way whatsover so please don't let that put you off at all. We decided we would like to do a day trip one day and Ligia organised for a private tour guide for us - his name is Billy and he's the best in Mexico I can assure you !!!! We had a fantastic day in Tullum and whatever we wanted to do and see Billy obliged. He is also the happiest and most energetic and bubbly tour guide you'll ever know and it's impossible to feel anything other than on top of the world in his presence. The 7 nights we stayed at The Tides were the best of our life - in fact, I'm not ashamed to say that when it came to saying goodbye I shed a tear or two!!!! It was worth every single penny and we highly, highly recommend it - you won't be disappointed.

Reviews.Title: “Fantastico”
Reviews.Author: SSSSOxford
Reviews.Content: We have just returned from 7 nights at this hotel and have to say it was perfect from start to finish, I had a mixed opinion reading the reviews before we travelled, and having stayed at many 5 star resorts previously was keeping an open mind. This hotel is complete escapism, it oooozes romance, the service is impecable and the standard of accom and food is extremely high. There is construction work outside the hotel but we couldnt hear a thing from our villa #12 or whilst wandering through the beautiful grounds of the hotel, so didnt affect us in any way whatsoever. The beach at the hotel is beautiful, a little rocky on the shore line but the sea is fantastic and definately recommend snorkelling as the fish are amazing. I have to say we will definately be returning to this hotel, as do most of the visitors to this hotel.

Reviews.Title: “7 Reasons Not to go...”
Reviews.Author: Ldn-0005
Reviews.Content: 1) There is a MAJOR CONSTRUCTION PROJECT taking place next to the hotel which you have to cross in order to get to the set down/ lobby _ v shabby welcome for an upmarket hotel. However, this was only a minor inconvenience compared to the NOISE POLLUTION from the construction. This started early in the morning and persisted all day. Our room was one of those furthest away and this was still a real nuisance. WE WERE OUTRAGED THAT THE HOTEL HAD NOT WARNED US OF THIS, especially given that this seems to be a condo complex built by the hotel. In hindsight I see why they took a 50% deposit on booking (& 2 week cancellation policy)! 2) During our entire 8 night stay the WOMEN' S SPA was OUT OF ORDER with no attempt to fix it! Gym was a joke, 2 ruining machines in a small sweaty room. 3) Hygiene: standard is v poor for a supposed smart hotel both in rooms as well as general (dirty covers on armchairs and worn out towels by pool) 4) Breakfast and lunch menu was the shame stodgy/ fatty food every day_ awful 5) OUTRAGEOUSLY OVERPRICED: How can 1 poolside pina colada and 1 smoothie cost USD 70?! (along with a host of other charges which are not mentioned on Website including 10% service charge on top of USD 700 room only rate) 6) Don't swim in the sea unless you have a death wish_ lots of dangerous jet skies in the shallows. Nothing done about this. 7) THE LOCATION is NOT nice _on a large strip of beach surrounded by construction sites and a number of large all inclusive type hotels. The Mayan ruins about 1 hour away are breathtaking but apart from that the region has little to offer upmarket couples on a romantic retreat. I feel bad being so critical given that waiting staff were very nice and the evening chef was very good but overall we left with a VERY SOUR taste in our mouths given the above & MANAGEMENT'S UNWILLINGNESS TO ADDRESS THESE ISSUES. My impression is that this is a hotel which is pretending (and pricing itself) as 5 star resort but does not understand/ not willing to do what is required in order get there_ especially when it comes to customer satisfaction.

Reviews.Title: “bad experience”
Reviews.Author: holidayfanxxx
Reviews.Content: My husband and I love to travel and I think I can say that we have seen a lot of places and always went to very nice hotels. Our benchmark is the Fourseason Hotels standard. We were traveling in October 2007, so due to the weather in Mexico we went to Cancun to be more save. We did know a bit about the hotel, as different friends of ours went to the hotel, but before it was taken over by the Tides. We did think that a new owner would even make it better. But we were so wrong! Before I start, we did live in NY and are now in London, so we are use to high prices, but being in Mexico … you do not expect higher prices than London. And on all you book (trips … diving, land visit etc. the hotel takes a 20% service charge). That was such an expensive trip, that going to the Maldives in August last year was much cheaper. But fine if you are willing to pay it you are at the right place. We new the room price, but were very surprised by the food and drinks. Ok, let’s first start with the good part … expensive, but the restaurant and the cook are super. The cook did learn his business in San Francisco and mixed a bit Mexican with French kitchen. Very often he came out and asked everyone if you are happy or if he can surprise you with something else. It was really yummy ! So, sadly that was all the good part. Let’s start with the bad information for you: 1. There is a big construction side next to the hotel and it does not bother the hotel as it is going to be their big new Residence style apartments. It was a not very nice arriving as you drive a bit thru that before coming to the reception. 2. Our first room was next/behind a wall to the construction and it was very noisy. Knowing that the hotel was just 40% (they told us before) booked, you do ask yourself why they give you that room and not start with the once far away from it. I was very unhappy when they did not want to change it in the first place and was told that I can turn on the whirlpool to hear it less. I got very angry by that and went nuts at the reception. 2 hours !!! later they did show me around a couple of other rooms and I did pick one, but still I was very sad that every room is so dark and still you can hear from all of them the digger from the construction. 3. New room, we settled in and went for a quick cocktail to the beach. We did –thanks god- put all our belongings in the save, but left some pocked money in my handbag. When we came back we surprised someone going thru our stuff, we could not see the face but saw the uniform. All the money was gone and our clothes and other stuff up side down. I did not feel save anymore. The hotel mentioned that sadly that was not the first time and they are working on it. With the uniform they knew the department of it but could not find out who it was. We got invited that night for dinner and wine, much more than went missing from our room, but I have to say they could not change my feeling about the safety for the coming week. 4. Due to the jungle style that hotel is build, first view very nice but you do have 24/7 mosquitos around. You have them in the room (no matter what you try to keep them out), during the day on the terrace as it is very dark without sunlight and it is very bad in the evening. Bring spray with you … and you have to put it on 24/7. I was still bitten all over the body and looked very stupid in my bikini. 5. The pool was not clean. I asked them to clean it and they removed the leaves out of it, but you still had everywhere moss in and around it. Recalling it, some of the rooms I have seen on the first days where even worse with moos. I all the days we were their we just went once in it. Sadly, it was a very disappointing holiday.

Reviews.Title: “Our second visit, was even better than the first!!!!!!!”
Reviews.Author: avid_travler
Reviews.Content: Often times, I hesitate to return to a vacation spot that we just love, fearing the return trip could not possibly meet our expections again. The Tides excede even our fondest memories. We were so happy to be greated once again by Victor and Jorge who actually really did remember us. Their warm welcome made us instantly glad we had decided to return. The new management had made a few changes from last year. We loved the new signs giving us a clue as to where we were headed. We also loved the new chef. His food was light, and flavorful, with a large variity of choices. The service remained excellent, and the property was emaculate. I cannot wait for our return visit. I look forward to Jacob serving me bloody mary's at the pool, making sure I was never hungry for anything. We look forward to our next visit, hopefully next year.

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful and worth it!”
Reviews.Author: mmj71076
Reviews.Content: We just returned from a wonderful 3 night/4 day stay at The Tides. The construction was not a problem at all (we heard a hammer twice). They have added waterfalls etc. to disguise what little noise there is. The rooms are very private and wonderfully decorated. The plunge pool was the perfect temperature and the outdoor shower was all we used. The service was as good as anywhere else, but more subtle then the Palmilla which we appreciated. Victor, Roger, and Jacob were all memorable in their service. And the food was incredible-tried all 5 kinds of ceviche and the breakfast menu is not to be missed. The Friday night BBQ by the pool in our case was a wonderful option. And the complimentary coffee and croissants brought to our room every morning was a nice way to start the day. I had a prenatal massage by the beach that was fabulous-better than I have had in Houston. This place is worth every penny-it is beautiful, very relaxing, with great service and food. It is very quiet so plan to unwind!

Reviews.Title: “Service outstanding”
Reviews.Author: HonestAbe2
Reviews.Content: When you are spending $900 per night for a hotel room that includes butler service, you expect a level of service that will knock your socks off. And that is precisely what you will find at the Tides Riviera Maya (former Ikal del Mar). My wife and I have stayed at some of the finest hotels in the world, and we have not yet experienced a hotel with a level of service comparable to what we had at the Tides. To be more specific, the hotel staff (significant in size in the context of a 30-room hotel) makes an effort to accommodate any desire you may have--they will set up a dinner table for you ANYWHERE on the property, and little surprises when we returned to our room (champagne, flowers, desserts, tequila tastings) made us feel special. They get to know you by name in a non-invasive way, and learn precisely what kind of drink you would like by your second day at the pool. The answer to any question is never "no," and if there is a request that cannot be satisfied, you are left convinced that it is certainly not for lack of trying. The spa is serene and unique in design. The poolside has a fantastic ambience with a direct view onto a nice stretch of beach. The rooms are spacious, and the plunge pools heat up almost like a jacuzzi if you request it. Surprisingly, we found ourselves using it despite the fact that it looked like it could get 'buggy" in the jungle setting based on what we saw on the Internet. If we were forced to level criticism, it might be that while the breakfast and lunch menu were good, the dinner menu lacked a little in excitement, and we found ourselves wanting to try something new after a couple of nights (this despite the fact that there is truly no more romantic place to dine anywhere than the seafront setting at the hotel). Additionally, the ocean directly in front of the hotel is a bit rocky and therefore does not invite you to swim, well-mitigated by the pleasant pool area with the ocean view that seemed to satiate our desires for the ocean experience. Moreover, while the beach directly in front of the hotel is very nice, we were not motivated to take beach strolls because of the less appetizing developments down the beach on either side (fortunately, not close enough to interfere with the serenity of the hotel's beachfront experience). The location of the hotel is an easy 30 minutes south of cancun airport. And with the exception of a wonderful day in Tulum for a change of scenery or Chichen Itza, there is really no reason to leave the tranquility of the hotel....which is a good thing considering the fact that Playa del Carmen (touted by some as "European" or "quaint") is a veritable lower-middle-class cesspool of low-end retail, characteristically "cheesy" and touristy bars, restaurants, etc, and seems to have very few redeeming qualities. In other words, avoid it. In summary, the Tides is certainly worth the money, has a truly superior level of service that promises not to disappoint, a unique seaside setting, and is generally the kind of place you would not want to leave. The spa services are "good", and we feel we had precisely the vacation that we deserved. Do not come here if you plan on casually meandering through a quaint Mexican town if you want or need a 'break" from the hotel's seaside (unless, of course, you are prepared to drive an hour to Tulum or perhaps take a day to see Chichen Itza). As a final recap, the hotel is luxurious without being pretentious, cool without being uncomfortable, serene and extremely service oriented. It seemed to cater just as well to people in their 30s as to those in their 60s, and cultivated a sort of serene "coolness" not intimidating to those of any age, and not passe or tired to Manhattanites who have "been there and done that." The crowd was diverse, and everyone seemed to converge on wanting the same type of holiday---a quiet, sunny place to get away and be pampered for a little while.

Reviews.Title: “A perfect 10!”
Reviews.Author: hfplaurie
Reviews.Content: My husband and I planned to stay at the Tides Riviera Maya for 5 nights in early December 2007 for a well-needed romantic getaway. We left the day after a foot of snow in Chicago and arrived in paradise by mid afternoon. It was so wonderful that we ended up extending our trip another 2 days and really could have stayed even longer. We didn't want to leave because we were so relaxed and pampered! Everything from the rooms, the service, the food, the spa, and the grounds was perfect! The rooms are absolutely beautiful. The beds were so comfortable I didn't want to get up in the morning. I loved the private jungle surrounding and waking up with the sounds of the birds outside, our coffee waiting on the patio, (and yes, occasional banging from the construction). The private pool and outside shower were real treats not to mention the unique turndown service at night, the handmade soap, and the great CD player (we brought our own CD's). The grounds themselves are exquisite too -- the pool, the dining area, all the little private nooks and crannies, and the spa. Since we are totally beach people, we hung out on the beautiful beach beds everyday and spent a lot of time in the water. I highly recommend bringing water shoes or, if not, they have some there to use as there are rocks in the water. We also had a couples massage at the spa and although it was not the best massage I ever had, the setting is beautiful and it was very relaxing. The service was wonderful too. The staff is very friendly, helpful, and jump the minute you move your little finger. There is nothing they will not try to do. By the end of our trip, we knew most of the staff and had a lot of fun joking around with them. Sometimes things moved a little slowly, but it is Mexico after all and sometimes I think it was a communication problem due to my bad Spanish. Jorge, the front desk manager, was particularly helpful so when I needed something, I usually just went to him. Now to the food... Chef Cupertino is a great chef with impeccable credentials, and a nice, young guy too. (Apparently The Tides recruited him and most of the kitchen staff from Las Ventanas). The food is outstanding but yes, it is expensive. Same with the drinks. I think it goes with the territory. If you're worried about being nickeled and dimed, then this is probably not the place for you. Just assume you're going to spend at least $1,000 night and enjoy it. We did go into Playa del Carmen one night for dinner (La Casa del Agua) and the meal was about 1/2 the price but about 1/2 as good. So the rest of the nights we stayed at The Tides. We did a couple excursions too while we were there. We went snorkeling one morning (it was average). Another day we did a combination trip to Tulum with snorkeling in a cenote (a freshwater cave). I highly recommend that. We went with Santiago (Pepe's partner) both times who was just the nicest guy ever. We also played golf at Mayakoba (very expensive) but my husband loved it. It's unfortunate that the construction will take away some of the ambience of the drive in (it must have been spectacular when it was all jungle). But unfortunately, there's building everywhere now. Also, a couple very small, minor suggestions: 1) Bring your own alarm clock. The wake up calls tend to run late. 2) The amenities in the bathroom are great (Molton Brown) but they don't supply shower caps. Since it's a rainshower head, the water comes straight down. If you don't want to wash your hair 3X day, bring your own shower cap. Overall, it was a perfect vacation in paradise! We have travelled extensively and generally stay at high end hotels and resorts. The Tides, however, was by far one of our favorite places EVER and I would definitely love to return again (which I don't say about a lot of places only because there are so many places in the world to go). Can't wait to go back!

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful”
Reviews.Author: ChitownCaribbeanFan
Reviews.Content: A beautiful spot. Rooms are great and amazingly private. Service in the room, on the beach, at the restaurant and at the spa is outstanding. Chef Cupertino Ortiz comes highly acclaimed (Palmilla and Las Ventanas in Cabo) and that acclaim is well deserved. Food was outstanding. Beach and pool are great, and seating (chaise lounges, double lounges, daybeds) is way more than adequate. Two minor shortcomings - the water in front of the resort is rocky, making it difficult to get in to, and hotels in either direction are large (Sandals and Princess). They are not visible from the Tides beach, but are close enough to produce a constant stream of beachwalkers. Yes, Tides is quite expensive, but we found it well worth the price.

Reviews.Title: “Impossibly perfect!”
Reviews.Author: EBGTM
Reviews.Content: The previous review said much of what i would have, so i don't need to write too much detail... But my husband and i would concur with everything they said! it was magical from the moment we stepped onto the property. our butler, oscar, was top notch as was his partner. the front desk staff was so friendly and always answered our calls from our room promptly and curtiously and directed us immediately to our butler. the spa was magnificent. while very different from others we've visited it was so unique. the frangrance, the noise of the jungle and waterfall and the wonderful therapists. we loved the mayan ritual that greeted us on our initial walk to our villa. regarding personalization- we asked for our "beach" dinner to be rellocated to the garden space, we had no idea how beautiful it would be. Sergio, our waiter, made sure the night was perfect (and it was!). Every day was better than the one before... well, we did go on the horseback ride on the beach on our first morning and that took the cake. we highly recommend this adventure. it was absolutely breathtaking. Again, we could go on and on but really, this place is so unique and we hope to return again soon (as soon as we replenish our check book! worth every penny!).

Reviews.Title: “Construction Noise? What Construction noise?”
Reviews.Author: Southpawfam
Reviews.Content: Reading the previous posts, we were a little concerned about the prospects of construction noise. We stayed Sunday night through Thursday and did not hear anything except the sounds of the jungle and the sea. Maybe the KOR management response is accurate. We arrived via the Tides Range Rover from Hotel Basico in Playa Del Carmen. That review can be found there. We were greeted as we stepped out with a moist cloth and chilled fresh coconut milk with a straw in the coconut. Very cool! Our personal butler took us on a brief tour of the resort and spa, then treated us to mojitos before taking us to our villa. The villa was spectacular. Very private and romantic. The outdoor shower seemed to have an unlimited supply of hot water. The personal pool was also heated to a nice temp. If I had to, I think I could live there! The beach and pool were incredible. My wife and I have traveled to many beaches around the world, and this is as good as any. The lounge chairs are spaced out nicely, and you never had to "save" a lounger at any time of the day. Don't even think about moving the lounge chair yourself...the attendant will jump right on it. They even would greet us with an ice cold water bottle after a walk on the beach. They were always one step ahead of us, anticipating our every move. I am still not sure how all the employees seemed to know us by name even though we had not been introduced before. The bar staff were very attentive without being a pest. The chef, Cupertino Ortiz, made sure my wife had her nightly Caprese salad with fresh Buffalo Mozzarella. The menu changed mid-week, and your dining options are plentiful. You can dine where you want when you want. The will literally put a table for you wherever you tell them you want it. The restaurant (upper deck) was a nice option on the one windy night. The whole atmosphere and ambiance was begging for some nice "chill" music. That would be our only complaint. What little there was, did not seem to fit the whole scene. If you are familiar with Nikki Beach...this is very much like that...just not with the right music. Jorge, the front desk manager, would check on us daily to make sure we were not lacking anything. Francisco would make sure the "others" would not wander in off the beach, and Jacob and Manual, made sure we had whatever we needed while on the beach or by the pool. The housekeepers also added their personal touches to our bed and linens each nite. Wireless internet throughout the property was really important to us, so we could keep in touch with our boys at home. There were also lots of little touches and small details that we noticed throughout the property that told us that this property wants to leave a lasting impression. The ratio of staff to guests is amazing. With only 30 rooms, I wonder if the staff outnumber the guests. Feel free to ask me any specific questions.

Reviews.Title: “Great place with some kinks”
Reviews.Author: xxyyzz1212
Reviews.Content: Got back recently from a stay there. The Tides has a lot going for it, but also has a ways to go. In brief: The dreaded construction is, in fact, a problem, as others have stated. Which villa you get is of paramount importance. And despite specifically requesting a villa away from the noise at the reservation stage, and having been assured that that would be possible, the unctuous butler/greeter guy tried, upon our arrival, to stick us in one of the villas closest to the construction. When we protested, he claimed the resort was 100 percent full. When we continued to protest, and drew his attention to the assurances that had been placed in our reservation file, he switched us, despite his initial claim that that would not be possible. In short, if they show you to one of the villas right near the construction (near the front entrance, in particular), you need to push back immediately. One gets the sense that they try to pawn those off on the unwary or timid. So stand up for yourself, both when you make the reservation and when you arrive. Not that you should have to, but there it is. That dispensed with, the place itself is extraordinarily nice. The grounds are gorgeous, the villas are comfortable and phenomenally romantic. Really, really nice, and, as others have said, exactly like the pictures on the website. So have no fear there. The service, with the exception of the quasi-management-level guys, we found to be excellent. Very friendly and quite efficient given its context. No complaint there. The food, we thought, was excellent, though expensive. The drinks, however, bordered on a scam--plain and simple. It's one thing to be expensive. It's quite another to be offensive. They'd make more money (an all-too-ill-concealed aim, at times) if they'd charge a still exorbitant but marginally more palatable 10 bucks for a margarita, say, than 15. I mean, as soon as you get the first drink bill, you basically go into a state of lockdown, which serves neither vacationer nor hotelier very well. The water shenanigans have been well and accurately documented by others so I won't go into that. The pool is very nice, and the beach too. The coral is a very minor issue, in my view, and I wouldn't let that scare you off. These midlevel guys who appear to run the place are kind of disastrous, though. After the hassles with checkin detailed above, all of which resulted in us not occupying our room until about 8 o'clock on the night of our arrival, one of these guys has the temerity to suggest that we'd need to vacate our room early(!) on the day of departure. Again, we pushed back and the ostensibly impossible became magically possible. But what a drag. A guest should never be made to feel that they're imposing--especially not at what after all is said and done amounts to well over a thousand bucks a day. Bottom line: This will be a great—I mean truly great, world-class—resort once the construction gets solved, the mid-level managers get a good talking to, and they figure out how to run an expensive resort with the class and tact that that kind of property demands. I, like many folks I think, will happily pay a very high room rate for the right product, but tend to blanch at what might be argued to be comparatively minor expenses, like 8-dollar sodas and 15-dollar margaritas. Why? It's symbolic. It screams "you're being taken advantage of"—it's a constant reminder of the expense of the vacation, and it can't help but call the intentions of the entire enterprise into question. It leads a guest to begin examining the value proposition of every aspect of the resort. And that's not something you want your guests to be doing. And, as a guest, it's not conducive to a relaxing vacation. I really liked this place. A lot. I just wish I were more eager to return.

Reviews.Title: “Not even close to worth it.”
Reviews.Author: stanleyd
Reviews.Content: As we discovered first hand this week, this hotel is still sufferning from major construction problems and The Kor Hotel Group has not, as implied in their response to a previous post, addressed this issue. Upon arriving and after waiting 3 hours for our room, we were led to villa 38 - one of many rooms that abutts the construction project next door. As we discovered, the construction extends onto the Tides property and as you can see from our pictures below, workers were camped outside of our 860$/night villa. There was no sense of privacy, or for that matter safety, with workmen literally hanging from the walls above our room. Beyond the very major construction issues - the food is mediocre at best as well as highly over priced. The beachfront is very pretty and the staff is very attentive. The villas, when not besieged by local workmen, are beautiful and the private pools are a very nice luxury. We contacted the Kor Group by email 3 times after arriving and still have not heard back.

Reviews.Title: “Heaven On Earth”
Reviews.Author: Blondie719
